questiontext.text:
Example

Let \(A = \{0,1\}\) and let \(B = \{2,3,4\}\).

Note that \(A\) and \(B\) have no elements in common. This is represented pictorially in the Venn diagram by circles which are totally separate from each other as shown in the figure below. Here, \(S\) denotes the universal set.

Figure: The sets \(A\) and \(B\) have no elements in common.


The complement of \(A\), denoted by \(A'\), is the set whose elements do not belong to \(A\). The set \(A'\) is shown in the figure below (the shaded area).

Figure: The complement of \(A\) contains elements which are not in \(A\).


Similarly, the set \(B'\) is shown in the figure below (the shaded area).

Figure: Everything outside of \(B\) (but within \(S\)) is \(B'\).
